Award.AbstractNarration: This project covers the concept and technical details of maintaining and operating (M&O) the IceCube Neutrino Observatory upon the completion of construction and deployment of the 86-string array under the MREFFC project. The University of Wisconsin (UW) offers their proven approach to providing M&O for IceCube based on their experience from both constructing the detector and starting its partial operation. Learned lessons that shaped this project include the need for: (1) resources for both distributed and centrally managed activities, and (2) additional accountability mechanisms for "in-kind" and institutional contributions; both are necessary to ensure that the detector maintains its capability to produce quality scientific data at the level required to achieve the detector's scientific discovery objectives. The project exploits a balance between the Core M&O tasks that are centrally funded through UW-Madison, and the "in-kind" tasks that are supported through the IceCube Collaborating Institutions. The success of the IceCube research will enhance scientific and technological understanding on many levels through broad dissemination of data and discoveries. The proposed distributed model of the IceCube M&O and scientific data analyses results in educational opportunities and mentoring at all levels, from undergraduates to postdoctoral researchers, and in a broad set of disciplines including operations, management, engineering, computing, and scientific research. IceCube is a unique detector that inspires innovative capacities of a new generation of scientists and engineers to solve the most vexing scientific problems by applying new knowledge about the Universe.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The IceCube Neutrino Observatory at the South Pole is the largest particle detector in the world. It continually looks for high-energy particles, cosmic messengers from outer space. Among the more than 100 billion particles detected per year are a few astrophysical neutrinos—neutrinos with the highest energies ever observed, which are likely to have been created in the most extreme environments in our universe. In November 2013, only three years after the completion of the detector, the IceCube Collaboration announced the discovery of astrophysical neutrinos. This science feat was highlighted in media around the world and was recognized as the Physics World Breakthrough of the Year in 2013.

The IceCube Neutrino Observatory’s science reach is broad, ranging from South Pole glacial climate reconstruction to searches for the sources of the highest energy particles in the universe. Many exciting results have been published in roughly one hundred scientific papers in refereed journals between 2010 and 2015. Significant improvements in all performance areas have produced a stable yet steadily more capable instrument that exceeds design expectations. This led to the first measurement of the cosmic ray anisotropy in the Southern Hemisphere, neutrino oscillation results that are competitive with dedicated experiments, and the world’s most stringent constraints for certain classes of dark matter searches.

The accomplishments of IceCube Collaboration members have been recognized with significant national and international prizes, including the 2014 Smithsonian Ingenuity Award, the 2015 Balzan Prize for Astroparticle Physics, two 2015 Global Neutrino Network dissertation prizes, and four International Union of Pure and Applied Physics prizes, consisting of three Astroparticle Physics Young Scientist Prizes (one in 2013 and two 2015) and the 2015 IUPAP-TIFR Homi Bhabha Medal.

IceCube’s neutrino alerts and data access plan enable collaborative efforts with an increasingly broader user base. Coordinated searches with leading cosmic-ray, optical, gamma-ray, and gravitational wave observatories have resulted in multiple publications, most recently a joint paper with the LIGO and ANTARES collaborations, setting limits on neutrino production in the first gravitational wave event ever detected.

Website and social media platforms—facebook and twitter—highlight on-ice activities at the South Pole, summarize recent publications, and describe noteworthy events and accomplishments. Media mentions that have been tracked since January 2015 include 170 news pieces appearing in 20 different countries, with over 50% of those in the US. The experiences of the team members at the South Pole are shared with audiences worldwide through real-time webcasts with the South Pole station, held several times per year and reaching hundreds of people in the US and around the world.
